definitions: move in a slow heavy awkward way typically making noise
burden someone with an unwanted responsibility or difficult task
examples: The old truck lumbered slowly up the steep mountain road
The bear lumbered through the forest searching for food
They lumbered me with organizing the entire company retreat
She got lumbered with babysitting duty every weekend

definitions: put together or consider as a single group without distinction
form or cause to form into lumps or masses
accept or tolerate something unpleasant because there is no alternative
examples: Don't lump all teenagers together when discussing social issues
They lumped the expenses into one final bill
The sauce will lump if you add flour too quickly
The clay lumped together in her inexperienced hands
If you don't like the new rules you'll have to lump it
She had to like it or lump it with the decision

definitions: eat a meal in the middle of the day
provide lunch for someone especially in a business context
examples: We usually lunch at the caf√© across from the office
She lunches with clients every Wednesday afternoon
The company will lunch all conference attendees in the main hall
They lunched the visiting delegation at an expensive restaurant

definitions: make a sudden forward thrust of the body typically to attack or grasp
move suddenly and forcefully in a particular direction
examples: The fencer lunged at his opponent with perfect timing
She lunged forward to catch the falling vase
The dog lunged toward the intruder barking fiercely
He lunged across the table reaching for the document

definitions: make an abrupt unsteady uncontrolled movement or series of movements
leave someone in a difficult situation without help or warning
examples: The ship lurched violently in the stormy seas
The drunk man lurched from side to side
They lurched us by canceling at the last minute
The company lurched its employees when it suddenly closed

definitions: tempt a person or animal to do something or go somewhere especially by offering a reward
attract or catch fish or animals using bait or decoy
examples: The company lured talented engineers with high salaries and benefits
She was lured into the scheme by promises of quick profits
Fishermen lure bass with plastic worms and spinners
The hunter lured the deer into the clearing with corn

definitions: have a very strong desire for something especially power or material things
feel strong sexual desire for someone
examples: He lusted after power and control over the company
Many people lust for fame and fortune
She found herself lusting after her attractive coworker
The character lusted for the beautiful princess

definitions: kill someone especially by hanging for an alleged offense without legal trial typically by a mob
examples: The angry mob threatened to lynch the suspected thief
Many innocent people were lynched during that dark period of history

definitions: write the words for a song or musical composition
examples: She lyrics all the songs for their indie band
He spent the weekend lyricing new material for the album

definitions: make or operate on something with a machine especially in manufacturing
shape or finish metal or other material using machine tools
examples: The factory machines thousands of parts every day
They machine the components to exact specifications
The workshop can machine custom aluminum parts for motorcycles
He machined the steel rod to the precise diameter

definitions: make someone extremely angry or irritated to the point of fury
become extremely angry or lose emotional control
examples: The referee's unfair decision maddened the entire team
It maddens me when people are deliberately cruel to animals
He maddened at the thought of such injustice
The crowd maddened when the concert was suddenly canceled

definitions: dye fabric or material using madder root to produce red color
examples: The textile workers maddered the cloth to achieve a deep red
They maddered wool yarn for traditional weaving projects

definitions: make something appear larger than it is especially with a lens or microscope
increase the intensity degree or extent of something
exaggerate the importance or seriousness of something
examples: The telescope magnifies distant stars thousands of times
Use this lens to magnify the small print
The microphone magnifies her voice throughout the auditorium
Alcohol tends to magnify our emotional responses
Don't magnify minor problems into major catastrophes
The media magnified the scandal beyond its actual significance

definitions: send a letter or package through the postal system
send a message or document through electronic mail
cover or protect with armor made of metal rings or plates
examples: Please mail the contract to our headquarters by Friday
She mailed birthday cards to all her grandchildren
I'll mail you the report as soon as it's finished
He mailed the presentation to the entire team
Knights were mailed in chain armor before battle
The warriors mailed themselves for protection

definitions: inject drugs directly into a major vein for immediate effect
give priority to something as a main focus or primary route
examples: The addict had been mainlining heroin for years
Some users dangerously mainline substances without medical supervision
The company decided to mainline their new product development
We need to mainline this project to meet the deadline

definitions: keep something in good condition through checking repairing or providing care
cause or enable a condition or situation to continue at the same level
assert something to be the case especially in the face of opposition
examples: The company maintains all its vehicles with regular service checks
She maintains her garden with daily watering and weeding
He maintains a steady pace throughout the marathon
The school maintains high academic standards every year
The defendant maintains his innocence despite the evidence
She maintains that the decision was entirely justified

definitions: specialize in a particular academic subject at college or university
examples: She majored in computer science at Stanford University
Many students major in business administration these days

definitions: form something by putting parts together or combining substances to create
cause something to exist or come about through action or behavior
compel or force someone to do something against their preference
earn or gain money or profit through work or investment
succeed in reaching or achieving a place or position in time
examples: She makes beautiful jewelry from recycled materials
The chef made a delicious soup from leftover vegetables
Your kindness really made my day so much better
The new policy will make a significant difference
Don't make me come over there and supervise
The teacher made the students rewrite their essays
He makes over six figures at his new job
The company made huge profits last quarter
We barely made the last train before midnight
She made the team after months of practice

definitions: fail to function normally or satisfactorily especially of equipment or machinery
examples: The elevator malfunctioned and trapped people between floors
His pacemaker malfunctioned requiring immediate medical attention

definitions: speak about someone in a spitefully critical way to damage their reputation
examples: The tabloids constantly malign celebrities with false stories
He was maligned by former colleagues jealous of his success

definitions: convert grain especially barley into malt by soaking germinating and drying for brewing
examples: The brewery malts its own barley for craft beer production
They malted the grain using traditional Scottish methods

definitions: perform the mambo dance with its characteristic hip movements and rhythm
examples: The couple mamboed across the dance floor with passion
She learned to mambo during her vacation in Cuba

definitions: provide a place or machine with the personnel needed to operate it
take one's position at a post or station ready for action
examples: The company will man the booth throughout the conference
They need to man the ship with experienced sailors
Soldiers manned their battle stations when the alarm sounded
Volunteers manned the phones during the fundraising telethon

definitions: be responsible for controlling or organizing someone or something especially a business
succeed in accomplishing or achieving something especially something difficult
cope or survive despite difficult circumstances with limited resources
examples: She manages a team of twenty software developers
He has managed the restaurant for over ten years
I managed to finish the project before the deadline
How did you manage to get tickets to the sold-out concert?
Single parents manage on very tight budgets these days
We'll manage somehow even with these challenges

definitions: officially require or command something through law or formal authority
give someone authority to act in a certain way on behalf of others
examples: The law mandates safety inspections for all commercial vehicles
The school board mandated new curriculum standards
Voters mandated the government to implement healthcare reform
The UN mandated peacekeeping forces to protect civilians

definitions: move skillfully or carefully in a confined space or difficult situation
carefully guide a situation to achieve a desired outcome often through clever manipulation
perform a movement or series of moves requiring skill and care especially military
examples: She maneuvered the car into the tight parking space
The captain maneuvered the ship through the narrow channel
He cleverly maneuvered himself into a promotion
Politicians constantly maneuver for political advantage
The troops maneuvered into position under cover of darkness
Fighter jets maneuvered through complex aerial formations

definitions: display or show a quality or feeling through one's actions or appearance
become apparent or obvious through signs or symptoms
examples: Her anxiety manifested in nervous laughter and fidgeting
The disease manifests through skin rashes and fever
Problems began to manifest after the system update
His talent manifested early in childhood

definitions: make copies of something especially using a manifold or duplicating device
examples: The secretary manifolded the memo for distribution
They manifolded documents before the age of photocopiers

definitions: control or influence a person or situation cleverly unfairly or unscrupulously
handle or control something with skill especially with the hands
alter or present data or information in a misleading way
examples: He manipulated his friends to get what he wanted
Advertisers manipulate consumers through emotional appeals
The surgeon carefully manipulated the delicate instruments
She manipulated the robot arm with precision controls
The company manipulated the financial data to hide losses
Someone manipulated the photos to remove important details

definitions: move skillfully or carefully especially in a confined or difficult space
carefully manipulate a situation to gain advantage
examples: The pilot manoeuvred the plane through severe turbulence
She manoeuvred the wheelchair through the narrow doorway
He manoeuvred his way into a senior position
The company manoeuvred to avoid the hostile takeover

definitions: cover envelop or conceal something like a cloak or layer
take on an important role or responsibility from someone else
examples: Snow mantled the mountain peaks throughout winter
Darkness mantled the city as the sun set
She mantled her father's leadership of the company
He mantled the responsibilities of department head

definitions: make goods or products on a large scale using machinery and labor
invent or fabricate evidence or stories especially to deceive
examples: The company manufactures electronic components for smartphones
They manufacture over ten thousand units per month
He manufactured an elaborate excuse for being late
The witness manufactured evidence to frame the defendant

definitions: apply animal dung or organic matter to soil to fertilize it
examples: Farmers manure their fields every spring before planting
We manured the garden beds with well-aged horse manure

definitions: represent an area on a map showing physical features and locations
plan something in detail establishing connections and relationships
establish a correspondence or association between elements of different sets
examples: Explorers mapped the uncharted territories of the Amazon
Scientists have mapped the entire human genome
We need to map our strategy for the next quarter
She mapped out her career path in detail
Researchers mapped brain activity to specific behaviors
The program maps keystrokes to specific functions

definitions: impair the quality or appearance of something by damage or injury
examples: Vandals marred the statue with graffiti and scratches
Nothing could mar her happiness on her wedding day

definitions: stain or streak something to look like marble with veined patterns
examples: The artist marbled the paper for book endpapers
She marbled the cake frosting with chocolate swirls

definitions: walk in a military manner with regular measured tread often in formation
walk quickly and determinedly in a specified direction with purpose
advance or progress steadily and inevitably over time
examples: The soldiers marched in perfect formation during the parade
Protesters marched through the streets demanding justice
She marched into his office and demanded an explanation
He marched straight up to the manager to complain
Time marches on regardless of our wishes or plans
Technology marches forward at an ever-increasing pace

definitions: make a visible impression or stain on something with ink or similar
indicate the position or presence of something for identification
assess and assign a grade or score to academic work
commemorate or celebrate an important event or occasion
examples: Be careful not to mark the white walls with dirty hands
She marked her name on all her belongings
Mark the correct answer with a checkmark
Trees mark the boundary between the two properties
Teachers spend weekends marking student essays and exams
The professor marked the papers very strictly
We marked our anniversary with a special dinner
The ceremony marked the end of an era

definitions: offer goods or services for sale especially in a market
promote or advertise a product or service to increase sales
examples: Local farmers market their produce at the weekend bazaar
The company markets its products globally
They marketed the new smartphone aggressively to young consumers
She successfully marketed herself as a consultant

definitions: abandon someone in an isolated or inaccessible place especially an island
examples: Pirates marooned the mutinous sailor on a deserted island
The storm marooned tourists at the remote mountain lodge

definitions: join together as spouses in a legally recognized union
perform a marriage ceremony uniting two people as spouses
combine or blend different elements successfully into a harmonious whole
examples: They married after dating for three years
She married him in a beautiful beach ceremony
The judge married them in a simple civil ceremony
The priest will marry the couple next Saturday
The chef marries traditional techniques with modern flavors
The design marries functionality with aesthetic appeal

definitions: arrange or assemble people or things in proper order especially for a purpose
gather and organize facts thoughts or resources for effective use
examples: The teacher marshaled the students into neat lines
Security marshaled the crowd toward the exits
She marshaled her arguments before the debate
He marshaled all available resources for the project

definitions: kill someone because of their religious or political beliefs
suffer greatly or sacrifice oneself for a principle or cause
examples: The regime martyred dissidents who opposed their rule
Many saints were martyred for their faith
She martyred herself working endless hours for the charity
Don't martyr yourself trying to please everyone

definitions: be filled with wonder or astonishment at something remarkable or unexpected
examples: Tourists marvel at the ancient architecture of the cathedral
Scientists still marvel at the complexity of the human brain

definitions: reduce food to a soft mass by crushing especially boiled vegetables
mix or combine different things especially in music or media
examples: Mash the potatoes while they're still hot
She mashed the bananas for the baby food
The DJ mashed several songs into one remix
They mashed different video clips together

definitions: conceal or disguise something especially feelings or intentions from being noticed
cover the face or another part with a mask for protection or disguise
examples: She masked her disappointment with a bright smile
The strong spices masked the taste of the medicine
Surgeons must mask before entering the operating room
The protesters masked their faces to avoid identification

definitions: pretend to be someone or something that one is not for deception
participate in a masquerade party wearing masks and costumes
examples: The thief masqueraded as a delivery person to gain entry
She masqueraded as a journalist to get the interview
Guests masqueraded at the Halloween ball until midnight
They masqueraded in elaborate Victorian costumes

definitions: deliberately and violently kill a large number of people especially helpless ones
examples: The invading army massacred innocent civilians in the village
Poachers massacred the elephant herd for their ivory

definitions: rub and knead muscles and joints to relieve tension or pain
manipulate figures or facts to give a more acceptable result
examples: The therapist massaged her sore shoulders for an hour
He massaged his temples to relieve the headache
The accountant massaged the numbers to improve the report
Politicians often massage statistics to support their claims

definitions: acquire complete knowledge or skill in a subject technique or activity
gain control or power over something or overcome a difficulty
make a master recording or original version from which copies are made
examples: She mastered three languages before graduating from college
It takes years to master the art of sushi making
He finally mastered his fear of public speaking
The captain mastered the ship through the storm
The band mastered their album at Abbey Road Studios
Engineers mastered the track for digital distribution
